Trivial Algebraic field extension
An algebraic field extension $L / K$ is trivial if every element of $L$ is algebraic over $K$.
Algebraic closure of a field
An algebraic closure of a field $K$, denoted as $\bar{K}$, is an algebraically closed field that is algebraic over $K$.
K-homomorphism
A field homomorphism \\(\sigma: L \longrightarrow L'\\) between two field extensions \\(L / K\\) and \\(L' / K\\) is called a \\(K\\)-homomorphism if it restricts to the identity map on \\(K\\).
Splitting field of Family of Polynomials

A splitting field of a family of nonconstant polynomials \\(\mathfrak{F}=(f_i)_{i \in I}, f_i \in K[X]\\) over a field \\(K\\) is a field \\(L\\) extending \\(K\\) such that: (i) Every polynomial \\(f_i\\) decomposes into a product of linear factors over \\(L\\). (ii) The extension \\(L / K\\) is generated by the zeros of the polynomials \\(f_i\\).
Normal field extension

A normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. It is a prestage to Galois extensions. An algebraic field extension \\(K \subset L\\) is called normal if it satisfies the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4: (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.
Finite Field

A finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\	ext{\_q}\]$ consists of $q$ elements, where $q=p^n$ for some prime number $p$ and integer $n>0$. It is different from the residue class ring $\\[\mathbb{Z} / p^n \mathbb{Z}\]$ for $n>1$, as the latter has nontrivial zero divisors and cannot be a field.
Prime Subfield of a Finite Field
The prime subfield of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is the smallest subfield contained within $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$, where $p=\operatorname{char} \\[\mathbb{F}\]>0$.
Splitting Field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield

A field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is a splitting field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ if the polynomial factorizes into linear factors in $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$. This implies that $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ contains all zeros of $X^q-X$.
Extension Field

An extension field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q / \mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field consisting of $q=p^n$ elements, where $p$ is a prime number and $n$ is a positive integer. This field is uniquely characterized up to isomorphism as a splitting field of the polynomial $X^q-X$ over $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$.
Algebraic Closure of Finite Field

An algebraic closure $\\[\overline{\mathbb{F}}_p\]$ of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ is a field that contains $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ and all its algebraic extensions. It is used to view the fields $\\[\mathbb{F}_{p^n}\]$ as subfields.
Multiplicative Group of a Finite Field
The multiplicative group of a finite field $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group formed by all nonzero elements of $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$, denoted as $\\[\mathbb{F}_q^*\]$. It is cyclic of order $q-1$.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.
Algebraic subset

An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: An algebraic closure of a field $K$ is defined as an algebraically closed field that is algebraic over $K$. Therefore, the concept of an algebraic field extension is necessary to define an algebraic closure.
A $K$-homomorphism is a field homomorphism between two field extensions $L / K$ and $L' / K$. Therefore, the concept of an extension field is necessary to define a $K$-homomorphism.
A splitting field of a family of polynomials over a field $K$ is a field extending $K$. Therefore, the concept of an extension field is necessary to define a splitting field.

A normal field extension is defined as an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. Therefore, the concept of a splitting field is necessary to define a normal field extension.
A finite field is uniquely characterized as a splitting field of the polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield. Therefore, the concept of a splitting field is necessary to define a finite field.
The prime subfield of a finite field is the smallest subfield contained within the finite field. Therefore, the concept of a finite field is necessary to define its prime subfield.

A field is a splitting field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield if the polynomial factorizes into linear factors in the field. Therefore, the concept of a prime subfield is necessary to define a splitting field of this polynomial.

An extension field $\mathbb{F}_q / \mathbb{F}_p$ is a field consisting of $q=p^n$ elements, where $p$ is a prime number and $n$ is a positive integer. Therefore, the concept of a finite field is necessary to define an extension field.

An algebraic closure of a finite field $\mathbb{F}_p$ is a field that contains $\mathbb{F}_p$ and all its algebraic extensions. Therefore, the concept of a finite field is necessary to define its algebraic closure.

The multiplicative group of a finite field $\mathbb{F}_q$ is the group formed by all nonzero elements of $\mathbb{F}_q$. Therefore, the concept of a finite field is necessary to define its multiplicative group.

The Galois group of a finite field extension $\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\mathbb{F}_{q'}$ that fix $\mathbb{F}_q$. Therefore, the concept of an extension field is necessary to define its Galois group.

An algebraic subset of $\bar{K}^{n}$ defined over $K$ is the set of common zeros in $\bar{K}^{n}$ of the polynomials belonging to a subset $E$ of the polynomial ring $K[X]$. Therefore, the concept of an algebraic closure is necessary to define an algebraic subset.
